meanings.definition: To persuade someone to do something by using force or threats.
meanings.sent1: The bully tried to coerce the smaller kids into giving him their lunch money.
meanings.sent2: The criminal tried to coerce the witness into changing their testimony.
meanings.sent3: The cat tried to coerce the mouse out of its hiding spot with a piece of cheese.
meanings.sent4: The storm clouds seemed to coerce the trees to bend in submission to the wind.
meanings.sent5: The teacher used a stern tone to coerce the students into completing their homework on time.

meanings.definition: To compel someone to act in a certain way.
meanings.sent1: The loud noise outside coerced the baby to wake up from her nap.
meanings.sent2: The urgent message from the boss coerced the employees to work late that night.
meanings.sent3: The delicious smell of freshly baked cookies coerced the children to come running to the kitchen.
meanings.sent4: The bright lights of the city coerced the young dreamer to chase after his ambitions.
meanings.sent5: The heartfelt plea from the charity organization coerced many people to donate to the cause.

meanings.sent1: The earthquake coerced the old building to collapse in on itself.
meanings.sent2: The strong winds coerced the fragile branches to break off from the tree.
meanings.sent3: The magician's spell coerced the rabbit to appear out of thin air.
meanings.sent4: The intense pressure coerced the diamond to form deep within the earth.
meanings.sent5: The determined hero's actions coerced the villain to surrender and give up his evil plans.
